did.unittitle: Michael and Susan Kahn collection of political cartoons
did.abstract: The Kahn Collection includes political cartoon art materials created in the United States and internationally covering a variety of subjects offering humorous social commentary and criticism on political topics of the day. The collection totals more than 14,220 items.
did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance through our electronic paging system using the request button located on this page.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English. Some materials are in Afrikaans, Arabic, Catalan, Chinese, Croatian, Czech, Danish, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Hebrew, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Russian, Spanish, Swedish, Turkish, Ukrainian and Vietnamese.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series 1 and Series 5 are open for research; as the collection is further processed, this finding aid will be updated with changing accessibility conditions. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

Portions of collection unprocessed. Material in Series 2-4 and Series 6-9 are unavailable for access. Please see LSC's Access to Unprocessed Collections Policy for more information about levels of discovery and access of special collections materials and registering interest in unprocessed collections.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.p: Gift of Michael and Susan Kahn, 2023.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Michael Kahn was born in Buffalo, New York on February 4, 1949. He moved to Southern California with Otto, his German immigrant father, and Eleanor, his New York-born mother, in 1951 and attended public schools in Los Angeles. He graduated from James Monroe High School in the San Fernando Valley and attended UCLA from 1966-1970, where he graduated magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa and was selected one of twenty honor seniors in a class of several thousand. He subsequently attended Stanford University enrolling simultaneously in the Law School and a PhD political science program. He graduated in 1973 after serving as the book review editor of the Stanford Law Review. He finished the entire PhD program but did not write a thesis and was awarded an MA in Political Science.

In 1973 Mike embarked upon two careers, one as a lawyer and another as a collector of political cartoons. His legal career commenced with a Clerkship with Judge Ben C. Duniway at the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco and his collecting career commenced with a trove of Puck cartoons purchased at the New Haven Book Barn near Yale. Eventually, Mike would collect tens of thousands of Puck cartoons as he compiled almost a complete run of the magazine which was published from 1877-1918. Mike also co-authored a highly acclaimed book on the history of Puck magazine entitled, What Fools These Mortals Be, the Story of Puck Magazine. Over his fifty-year collecting career Mike exhibited his Puck cartoons numerous times and gave dozens of lectures on the magazine. The highlights of these activities included a memorable program at the New York Historical Society in 2014 introducing the book and a spectacular exhibition of Puck cartoons at the Billy Ireland Museum at the Ohio State University in 2015-2016.

Mike's collecting career took him all over the world as he visited bookstores, museums, antique stores and booksellers' homes to collect books and magazines about or containing political cartoons. Eventually Mike collected cartoons from 59 countries including numerous bound volumes of magazines from the 19th century which were virtually non-existent in the United States. In 2007 Mike displayed the highlights of his collection at the Grolier Club of New York in an exhibition that lasted two months which was accompanied by a catalog containing the best examples of the show.
Mike amassed his collection of American cartoons by visiting bookstores and other outlets throughout the United States for over forty years. He also appeared on television shows, panels and programs, radio shows and other media outlets discussing his cartoons. In 2022 his collection was featured in the cover story of Fine Books and Collections magazine. He also sponsored numerous programs which promoted the utilization of political cartoons by secondary and college teachers and professors including the Opper Program at Ohio State University and a lecture series using political cartoons at the University of California, Davis.

In 2005 Mike published the only book ever distributed displaying political cartoons about the Supreme Court and the Constitution entitled May It Amuse the Court. Since then, Mike has delivered dozens of lectures on the subject matter of the book to a wide variety of audiences.

Mike's collecting career overlapped with his legal and political career. He was a trial lawyer and was eventually elected to the California Trial Lawyer Hall of Fame. Mike also served in over a dozen government positions including serving as the head of State agencies under Governors Gray Davis, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Gavin Newson during California's electricity and wildfire crises. Mike rounded out his activities with service on numerous charitable, civic, and business boards.
In 2022 Mike entered semi-retirement with his wife Susan.
Source: Biography written by donor, Michael Kahn, 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Kahn Collection includes political cartoon art materials created in the United States and internationally covering a variety of subjects offering humorous social commentary and criticism on political topics of the day. The collection totals more than 14,220 items including: approximately 1,047 prints and ephemeral items, 10,778 unbound periodicals, centerspread and single page illustrations, 884 bound periodical volumes, 1,511 books, exhibition catalogs and pamphlets, and 11 record cartons containing research, teaching and subject files. A wide range of different types of works on paper are included in the collection documenting countless subjects and targets of political cartoonists around the world from about 1690 to 2022. Includes original drawings, prints, broadsides, illustrated envelopes, photographs, playing cards, unbound periodicals, bound periodicals, books and pamphlets. Printing methods include engravings, etchings, lithographs, pen and ink, hand coloring, woodblock, presses, and digital printing.

Spanning over three centuries, the Kahn Collection is diverse and international in scope. While many of the subjects are political in nature, there is also a good deal of satirical matter focusing on industry figures, artists, performers, writers, publishers, and others - from well-known celebrity figures to stereotypes of people on all different levels of society. Strengths include: American and British historical political broadsides and prints, newspapers, magazines, bound periodicals and books, pamphlets, and exhibition catalogs; works of Hogarth, Gillray and their contemporaries; portraits and caricatures of Abraham Lincoln and other 19th century American political and industry figures; Thomas Nast published drawings in pamphlets, books, and magazines including Harper's Weekly; and extensive and/or entire runs of some periodicals including Vanity Fair.

The collection includes representation by the cartoonists of at least 59 countries and territories, including: Argentina, Australia, Austria, the Bahamas, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Burma/Myanmar, Canada, China, Costa Rica, Croatia, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Ecuador, Egypt, Finland, France, German Democratic Republic (East Germany), Germany, Greece, Guatemala, Hungary, India, Iran, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Netherlands/Holland, New Zealand, Nicaragua, Norway, Panama, Peru, Poland, Portugal, Puerto Rico, Romania, Russia/U.S.S.R., Scotland, Serbia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Tanzania, Turkey, Ukraine, United Kingdom/Great Britain, the United States, Uruguay, Venezuela, Viet Nam and Yugoslavia.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection has been arranged in the following series:
Series 1: American Art, Prints, Broadsides and Ephemera, 1798-2020
Series 2: American Unbound Periodicals, 1811-2021
Series 3: American Bound Periodicals, 1842-1968
Series 4: American Books, Exhibition Catalogs and Pamphlets, 1826-2022
Series 5: International Art, Prints, Broadsides and Ephemera, circa 1690-2010
Series 6: International Unbound Periodicals, 1799-2017
Series 7: International Bound Periodicals, 1798-2017
Series 8: International Books, Exhibition Catalogs and Pamphlets, 1715-2022
Series 9: Research, Subject Files and Collection Information, circa 1944-2022

did.unittitle: 1. American Art, Prints, Broadsides and Ephemera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 1 contains approximately 454 original drawings, digital prints, engravings, etchings and ephemeral items. Strengths in print materials depicting American presidential elections of 1828-2020 (with the bulk of items documenting aspects of the elections between 1840 and 1908). Notable items are: the original drawing of Rollin Kirby's Tammany (1928) which received the Pulitzer Prize for its satire on New York's Tammany Hall; several prints each by: Edward Williams Clay, John L. Magee, and David Levine; art, prints, and broadsides in a number of areas in early American history including an engraving by an unknown creator during the Early Republic titled Congressional Pugilists (1798) and several William Charles etchings commentating on the British and the War of 1812 (1812-1815) including: John Bull and His Baltimoreans (1814), Johnny Bull and the Alexandrians (1814), John Bull making a new batch of ships to send to the lakes (circa 1814), and The Hartford Convention (circa 1814); cartoon commentary on the "coffin bills" including James Akins' 1828 lithographic prints The Pedlar and his Pack or the Desperate Effort, an Over Balance; and the rare prints British Warfare in 1812, 1837-38 (1838) and Trouble in the Spartan Ranks (1843). Ephemera group includes some photographic prints and carte-de-visite, postcards, playing cards, illustrated metamorphosis envelopes, illustrated Civil War and World War II envelopes, a musical score and a calendar. Notable items include a clutch of rare illustrated Civil War era envelopes satirizing the capture of Jefferson Davis, carte-de-visite depictions of Davis, and metamorphosis envelopes featuring Martin Van Buren and William Henry Harrison (1840) and A Locofoco Before and After the Late Election: Hurra for Cass! / What! Old Zack Elected! (1848) .

did.unittitle: Off in a Bunch: The Same Old Races on the Same Old Track

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Color print depicting a race track showing an animal race on a track with various animals competing. A leader board alongside the track lists names: Bill Taft, Bill Bryan, Gene Chafin, Tommy Hisgen, Tommy Watson, Gene Debs and Preston. These were candidates in the 1908 U.S. presidential election.

did.unittitle: "International Debt Conferences (Listening In)"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unknown artist for unknown publication at unknown date. Original cartoon drawing, probably pencil and crayon on paper. Depicts a figure who represents "the world" (a well-dressed man in suit, bow tie and top hat with cane, with a globe head and human face) with one hand cupped to his ear near some swinging doors, listening in on conversation. He looks curious and worried. The doors are marked "International Debt Conferences". The drawing is signed "A.V." (sp?) Above the drawing in pencil is written "Listening In". Below the drawing in pencil editorial remarks are noted: 675. 3 cols. P.M. ED. PG. Tues. (possibly indicates this drawing was to be published in a newspaper 3 columns wide in the evening edition on the editorial page on a Tuesday). No text written on verso.

did.unittitle: Roosevelt: the Peace Victor. The President's Song
did.physdesc: Unbound 3 pages of sheet music with colored cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sheet music with lyrics regarding the Treaty of Portsmouth that formally ended the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905). Roosevelt was instrumental in the negotiations and this led to his being awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

did.unittitle: Literary Caricatures by David Levine from the New York Review of Books [15 prints with listing page contained in paper presentation folder]
did.physdesc: 1 folder containing 15 prints and index page.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The New York Review of Books was founded in 1963. David Levine began drawing illustrations for the publication shortly after it was established and drew thousands of caricatures of famous artists, politicians and writers over the course of his career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Still Standing [Photographic print of window (possibly in New York City) showing 9/11 reaction cartoon with Manhattan skyline and Uncle Sam's legs as the Twin Towers]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Print of photo depicting a cartoon displayed in a window showing New York City after 9/11, smoke billowing from lower Manhattan as the legs of what appears to be Uncle Sam stand in place of the Twin Towers (World Trade Center), his clenched fist visible as well. The caption reads: "Still standing. Thanks to all the police, firemen, and volunteers of this fine country."

A gravestone in background notes "Here Lies Democratic TIger - Greatly Mourned by the Bereaved Filibusters."

did.unittitle: British Warfare in 1812, 1837-38.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Political cartoon to garner anti-British sentiment in reaction to the 1837 "Caroline affair" and the Canadian independence movement. Subsequently, the incident led to the "Caroline test" legal principle still applied today (anticipatory self-defense) to international law.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Currier & Ives produced many of the important decorative prints of 19th century America. Their hand-colored lithographs covered a wide range of every phase of mid-century life and history, from city and country views, family life, portraits, comic prints, sports, etc., to political cartoons and newsworthy illustrations. These pictures were made by most of the celebrated artists of the time such as Thomas Nast, Otto Knirsch, Thomas Worth, as well as many others. Immensely popular and cheap, these prints were widely distributed but often mishandled and few survive today. Prints marked "N. Currier, N.Y." date from 1835 when Nathaniel Currier opened his lithographic shop until 1857 when James Ives became his partner and the firm's prints were marked "Published by Currier & Ives" from then on until the firm was liquidated in 1907. During that time the firm was carried on by the sons of the founders and flourished until the advent of chromolithography and photo-engraving in addition to the growing popularity of the illustrated newspaper caused their manual method of printing to become obsolete and unfashionable. (Source: Seller's note, see file)

did.unittitle: The Siege of Plymouth A.D. 1874
did.physdesc: 1 Lithograph. Double page spread; fold down middle causing possible separation of two halfs. All corners missing pieces; missing corners do not compromise artwork.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depiction of a battle scene with caption: The Siege of Plymouth A.D. 1874. A building in the background labeled Plymouth appears to be the Plymouth Congressional Church in Brooklyn, NY, which Henry Ward Beecher headed in 1874, when he was the subject of the Beecher-Tilton Scandal Case which culminated in an 1875 adultery trial for Beecher.

did.unittitle: [Portfolio of cartoon prints by Harold Talburt with informational brochure and card from Scripps advertising department]
did.physdesc: Includes 24 prints in each portfolio. Includes a folder with 2 copies of a promotional brochure and 2 copies of a card from the advertising department at Scripps Howard before the 2 portfolios.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Talburt's cartoons appeared in all of the Scripps-Howard papers, but he was based in DC on the Washington News.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of 24 cartoons, printed 18" x 15" and one to a sheet, along with a four-page promotional booklet, distributed to newspaper editors considering buying Talburt's cartoons. Subject matter includes President Franklin D. Roosevelt, the New Deal, the U.S. economy, federal government programs, World War II, Japan, Hitler and the Nazis, Mussolini and fascism.

did.unittitle: [Untitled cartoon drawing of Senator Edward Kennedy driving former President Jimmy Carter (in scuba gear).]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Editorial cartoon print (6/20). Senator Edward Kennedy driving with Jimmy Carter (in scuba gear)in the back seat. Kennedy looks back at Carter suspiciously. Inscribed with pencil, "Oliphant 91".

did.unittitle: [Untitled cartoon pencil drawing of an elephant (wearing a "76" jersey") and a peanut, sitting on opposite ends of a teeter totter.]
Bad Dictators Our Enemies - Good Dictators Our Allies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A woman (possibly Condoleezza Rice) sits at a large desk with her hands folded and resting atop a desk blotter with a piece of paper while she twiddles her thumbs. She is flanked by two American flags and two file boxes marked "Bad Dictators Our Enemies" and "Good Dictators Our Allies".

did.unittitle: Dear Mom and Dad, Happy New Year 2020!

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An elderly soldier with an American flag tattoo and wearing a helmet marked US Army crouches in an alley behind an oil drum. He is writing a letter that says, "Dear Mom and Dad, Happy New Year 2020!" He is located in Iraq, which is evidenced by a nearby abandoned car's license plate marked "Iraq", and a background consisting of several minarets, a black helicopter flying overhead, and something unseen smoking and burning.

did.unittitle: Dubya's Construction - Renovations. Nation building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A work truck marked "Dubya's Construction. Renovations. Nation Building." The truck is parked near a sidewalk, in front of a house labeled "Iran." A figure dressed as Uncle Sam stands in front of the house asking the occupant in the doorway, "I've been doin' some work in the neighborhood.... can I interest you in a free estimate?" Meanwhile, the two buildings to the left, labeled "Iraq" and "Afghanistan" have already been destroyed and smoke can be seen still smoldering in the rubble.

did.unittitle: Election 2000, Sing [opera singer]
did.physdesc: 1 Digital print. Work is inscribed, "4/20 For Michael Kahn. Best wishes from Pat Oliphant MM [2000]"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Digital print, 4/20. Original editorial cartoon work by Pat Oliphant, Universal Press Syndicate, copyright 2000. Depicts a stage and audience at an opera. A woman (opera singer) dressed in Viking attire stands on the stage holding a spear in her left hand and a shield in her right hand with the text: Election 2000. She is viewed from behind looking toward audience while a man front and center holds a card reading "SING". Oliphant's character Punk is featured in lower right corner commenting, "This is the fat anti-defamation league!." Work is inscribed by creator in pencil, "4/20 For Michael Kahn. Best wishes from Pat Oliphant MM [2000]"

did.unittitle: I, George W... (wink). Do solemnly swear... (wink)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Digital print, 1 of 20. Original editorial cartoon work by Pat Oliphant, Universal Press Syndicate, copyright 2000. Depicts President George W. Bush standing in front of Chief Justice William Rehnquist at Bush's first inauguration. Rehnquist is performing the swearing in ceremony; Bush's left hand is placed on a Bible and his right hand is held up to take oath. Bush says" I, George W..." (wink) and Rehnquist replies, "Do solemnly swear..." (wink).Oliphant's character Punk is featured in lower right of panel commenting, "You wanna hear some solemn swearing?" Print is signed and inscribed in pencil by creator, "1/20. To Michael Kahn from Pat Oliphant MMI".

did.unittitle: OKAY! Has anyone seen my wallet?

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Kevin Kallaugher ("KAL") is an American political cartoonist for The Economist and the Baltimore Sun. He has contributed cartoons to many newspapers and magazines in the U.S., Britain, Australia, France, Germany, and around the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Uncle Sam stands between two vacuums, holding his hat in his right hand and scratching his head with his left hand, asking, "Okay! Has anyone seen my wallet?" The oversized vacuums are pushed by members of the US Army and possibly the US Army Corp of Engineers. The soldier pushes a vacuum marked "Iraq" and the Corp member pushes a vacuum marked "Katrina". The vacuums are noisily (Vroooom! Slurp!) sucking up wads of cash and a sign in the foreground states "Caution Cleaning Under Way."

did.unittitle: Stem Cells Research - Science

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A hooded monk figure appears as an inquisitor, holding a torch in his right hand and wearing a large Christian cross around his neck. The torch is held toward a large stack of paper labeled "Stem Cells Research" while a distressed man in a lab coat wearing a sign marked "Science" stands tied up apparently about to be burnt at the stake like a witch or heretic.

did.unittitle: Climate Change is a Hoax

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original color editorial cartoon depicting a disgruntled looking man standing in a body of water holding a sign reading "Climate change is a hoax." He appears to be standing north of the Gulf of Mexico (possibly in Texas or Louisiana) while west of him, the United States is on fire or already burnt; to the east the clouds are pouring rain onto the land causing catastrophic flooding (people are shown drowning, homes and vehicles float in the water); additionally, fish and other marine life are shown dead, floating in the waters of the Gulf, Caribbean and Atlantic Ocean near Florida.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In the 1980 Winter Olympic Games, in Lake Placid, New York, the USA ice hockey team beat the Soviet team in a major upset deemed "The Miracle on Ice."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four ice hockey players in full gear ascend a grassy hill raising an American flag, reminiscent of the famous February 23, 1945 A.P. photograph by Joe Rosenthal entitled "Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima." The players' names and numbers are shown at least partially on their jerseys: Mark Wells (15), Dave Christian (23), Mark Johnson (10), and Jim Craig (30).

Smith is standing tall amongst New York City high rises holding his arms out and smiling. A steam ship passes by on the river in the foreground. did.unittitle: 5. International Art, Prints, Broadsides and Ephemera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains approximately 593 drawings, prints, engravings, etchings, lithographs, broadsides, and ephemeral items. The earliest prints found in the collection are two German prints (circa 1690) by unknown creators: Don Miguel Zorrero Tuerto Cavellero de las Trencadas and Thro excedenz herr Oswald von Stroblbardt Injuriarum Licentiatus Other rare, early prints include Hogarth's works: Judith an Oratorio of Sacred Drama (circa 1732), the series A Harlot's Progress (1733), Datur vacuum (1736), and The Bench (1758). Contains several rare prints depicting King George III, early America, and the American Revolution: Farmer G--e Studying the Wind & Weather (1771), The Yankee Doodles Intrenchments Near Boston (1776), The Tea Tax Tempest (circa 1781) and A picturesque view of the state of the nation (1778). Other notable items include: two Chinese political cartoon prints by an unknown artist (circa 1975) and two S.C. Milter prints from India (1894). The collection is particularly strong in the number of James Gillray etchings published from 1782-1809, the majority of which were printed in London by publisher Hannah Humphrey.

The ephemeral group includes calendars, cigarette cards, playing cards, trading cards, photographic prints, postage stamps, and postcards. Notable materials include War Cartoons No. 1-140 (1917-1918), a set of World War I era Black Cat cigarette cards illustrated by Louis Raemaekers, and an envelope of unpublished photographic prints documenting events in Tiananmen Square (circa May-June 1989) by an unknown photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The British Museum record (AN81135001) description: Fox is being chaired by demons, who advance toward flames (left) in which stands a devil with a pitch-fork waiting to receive him. Fox, seated, holding out his hat, his left hand on his breast says, "Westminster was pretty Hot but this much more so". The demons who support Fox's chair and prance along behind it appear to have been copied from the Devil in BMSat 6283. The foremost has the same twisted ram's horns, the claws of a bird of prey, and barbed tail. He shouts "Fox for Ever." His companions resemble him with slight variations...

did.unittitle: John Bull visited with the Blessings of Peace. No. XX
Amusement for John Bull & his Cousin Paddy, or, the Gambols of the American Buffalo, in St. James's Street

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A large buffalo, representing America, has created havoc on St. James Street. A woman peddler has fallen over and spilled her basket of fish and bread onto the street, and English ministers rush to grab the goods. Two fight among themselves. Each minister makes a statement. George III watches the entire scene from a window and smiles. A delightful English satirical print on the American war. Cresswell 857. (Source: seller's note, see file.)

did.unittitle: The Yankee Doodles Intrenchments near Boston 1776

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Behind a well-made trench, fronted with palisades, appear the heads of its defenders; words issue from their mouths in long labels. One man stands on the top of the trench, his cap is inscribed Death or Liberty, his coat and stockings are ragged, and he stands as if shivering with cold, his bayonetted musket tucked under his arm and pointing downwards; he says I swear its plaguy Cold Jonathan; I don't think They'll Attack us, Now You... [SOURCE: Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires, number 5329]. Man depicted at far right is American General Israel Putnam [SOURCE (in this collection): George Washington's War: In Caricature and Print, p. 166)

did.unittitle: [Untitled, copy of work featuring an interior scene in a home, people gathered around a table]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy of an image, possibly a painting. Kippenheim 1860 is written in lower right corner of work. (Kippenheim is a city in Germany.) Interior scene in a home with people gathered around a table for a meeting, looking intent and dismayed while listening to a young man speak. People bring food to the table as cats play on the floor in the foreground.

did.unittitle: The Rake's Progress (New Series) (After Hogarth), Reprinted from St. Stephen's Review.
did.physdesc: 1 Lithograph. Oblong folio. Leather and cloth. Cover completely separated from binding. Back cover looks like it has termite damage with a hole all the way through. Does not affect illustrated pages of interior. 15 x 11 x .25

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The St. Stephen's Review was a weekly political publication published in London from about 1883 to 1892. Tom Merry was the stage and pen name of British performer and cartoonist William Mecham.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes 9 full color illustrations published in St. Stephen's Review between June-August 1884. Each illustration, except one, includes a full page narrative of the Rake's Progress story.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Cappiello was a caricaturist, painter and poster designer who was born in Italy and worked mainly in France.

did.unittitle: El Ahuizote (semanario feroz): Tomo I
did.physdesc: 1 Reprint. Hardbound presentation folder inside of an illustrated paper cover.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: El Ahuizote was a political satire magazine published in Mexico City, Mexico from about 1874-1876. The name "El Ahuizote" has been used for more than one Mexican periodical title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include a hardbound presentation folder inside of an illustrated paper slip cover with a run of 1989 reprints of issues of El Ahuizote from February 5-July 31, 1874 plus an informational booklet.
